title: Simplify CCB to Claude+Codex Only
description:
Simplify Claude Code Bridge from a 5-provider, multi-platform system to a minimal 2-provider (Claude + Codex) solution for **macOS + Linux only** (no Windows, no WSL).

- Providers: keep **codex** + **claude** only; remove **gemini/opencode/droid**
- Platform: remove Windows/WSL compatibility and Windows-specific artifacts
- UX: replace `pend` with **reply-via-ask**; `ask` becomes **pure async** (submit-only)
- Remove MCP delegation integration (`mcp/ccb-delegation`, `ccb droid setup-delegation`)
- Keep both tmux + WezTerm backends

- Keep repo green per-layer: `python -m compileall -q lib bin ccb` + targeted `pytest`.
- No ‚Äúread results from logs‚Äù UX (no `pend`, no completion hook prompting `pend`).

title: Ensure per-project session isolation (repo A vs repo B)
description:
Ensure CCB maintains strict per-project session isolation when multiple repos are active simultaneously.

User scenario:
- Repo A: `claude` + `codex` sessions
- Repo B: `claude` + `codex` sessions
- Commands run inside repo A must talk only to repo A sessions, never repo B (and vice-versa).

## Requirements
- Default behavior: strict project isolation via `.ccb_config/` anchor.
- Cross-project routing must remain opt-in only:
  - explicit `--session-file` / `CCB_SESSION_FILE`, or
  - `CCB_ALLOW_CROSS_PROJECT_SESSION=1`

## Implementation notes
- Preserve/verify `claude_session_resolver.resolve_claude_session()` filters registry lookups by `ccb_project_id` when strict_project.
- Ensure the new direct-send `ask` path (s7t.9) resolves sessions *only* for the current project, and errors out if no `.ccb_config` anchor exists.

## Tests
Add tests that set up two fake projects with different `.ccb_config` roots and registry records, and verify:
- In project A, resolution never returns project B even if `CODEX_SESSION_ID`/`CCB_SESSION_ID` env vars point to B.
- In project B, likewise.

## Verification
- `python -m pytest test/ -q --tb=short`
- Manual: run two repos in parallel; `ask` from each repo routes to the correct local panes.

DEPENDS ON
  ‚Üí ‚óã claude_code_bridge-s7t.9: Make ask direct-send (no daemon / no polling)
close_reason: Added tests ensuring claude/codex sessions remain project-isolated by default (repo A vs repo B).

title: Investigate multi-pair isolation (multiple Claude+Codex pairs per repo)
description:
Determine if it's possible to run multiple isolated (Claude+Codex) pairs in a single repo, where:
- **Within a pair**: Claude can talk to Codex (and vice versa)
- **Across pairs**: Pair A cannot communicate with Pair B

## Use cases
1. **Parallel workstreams**: Two developers working on different features in same repo
2. **A/B testing**: Compare approaches with isolated AI pairs
3. **CI/CD**: Multiple pipeline jobs with isolated AI assistants

## Current architecture
- Session files: `.ccb_config/.codex-session`, `.ccb_config/.claude-session`
- Project isolation: `project_id.py` uses `.ccb_config` anchor
- Pane discovery: Based on session files in project root

## Design questions
1. **Session namespacing**: Could use `CCB_PAIR_ID` or similar to namespace sessions?
   - `.ccb_config/.codex-session.pair-1` vs `.ccb_config/.codex-session.pair-2`
   
2. **Pane isolation**: How to ensure `ask codex` from Pair A only reaches Pair A's Codex?
   - Pane title markers: `CCB-pair1-codex` vs `CCB-pair2-codex`
   - Session file filtering by pair ID

3. **Launcher changes**: `ccb` would need `--pair-id` or similar flag
   - `ccb --pair-id=1 codex,claude`
   - `ccb --pair-id=2 codex,claude`

4. **Environment propagation**: `CCB_PAIR_ID` must be inherited by spawned processes

## Complexity assessment
- Low: Just session file naming + env var
- Medium: Pane discovery changes + launcher flags
- High: Full multi-tenancy with access control

## Notes
- This is exploratory; may not be worth implementing
- Current per-project isolation (repo A vs repo B) already provides some separation
- Could be a post-simplification feature if there's demand
close_reason: Closed per user request (multi-pair isolation exploration not needed).

title: Add --reply-to flag and response markers to protocol
description:
Add support for reply-via-ask correlation with a `--reply-to` flag and reply markers.

## Protocol
Request (existing wrap style):
```
CCB_REQ_ID: <req_id>

<message>

CCB_DONE: <req_id>
```

Result/Reply (sent by callee):
- Callee sends a result back via `ask <caller> --reply-to=<req_id> ...`
- `--reply-to` should default to a **result/notification** payload (i.e., do not wrap with ‚Äúend with CCB_DONE‚Äù instructions).

Example payload:
```
CCB_REPLY: <original_req_id>
CCB_FROM: <sender_provider>
[CCB_RESULT] No reply required.

<answer>
```

## Files to MODIFY
- `bin/ask`
  - Add `--reply-to=<req_id>`
  - When set, inject `CCB_REPLY:` and `CCB_FROM:` lines
  - Make `--reply-to` imply `--no-wrap` (or equivalent) to avoid triggering a reply loop
- `lib/ccb_protocol.py`
  - Add marker constants: `REPLY_PREFIX = "CCB_REPLY:"`, `FROM_PREFIX = "CCB_FROM:"`

## Verification
- `ask claude --reply-to=<id> --no-wrap "..."` delivers a marked result message
close_reason: Implemented --reply-to marker injection and protocol constants

title: Make ask direct-send (no daemon / no polling)
description:
Make `ask` **submit-only** and **daemon-free** by sending directly to the target tmux/WezTerm pane.

## Key principle
CCB must not tail/monitor provider logs to fetch ‚Äúlatest result‚Äù. CCB must also avoid any blocking wait loops (sleep/poll) in the `ask` path.

Results are delivered only via the interactive panes (human-visible) and the reply-via-ask pattern (when implemented).

## Intended behavior
- `ask <provider> <message>` resolves the target provider session + pane, then `send_text()` directly via the terminal backend.
- `ask` prints the generated `req_id` (for correlation / `--reply-to`) and exits immediately.
- No `askd`, `caskd`, `laskd` requirement; no background shell scripts.

## Files to MODIFY (minimum)
- `bin/ask`
  - Remove unified `askd` submission path and background/nohup script path
  - Implement direct-send for `codex` and `claude`
  - Always print `req_id` and exit (pure async)
- `bin/ccb-mounted`
  - Redefine ‚Äúmounted‚Äù as: active session file exists + pane is alive/reachable (no daemon ping)

## Follow-ups (separate beads)
- Delete `askd` code once `ask` no longer imports/uses it.
- Delete provider-specific CLIs/daemons (`cask`, `lask`, `caskd`, `laskd`) once `ask` fully replaces them.

## Verification
- `ask codex "hi"` returns immediately with a `req_id` even if no daemon is running.
- No log-tail style logic in the `ask` path:
  - `rg -n "CodexLogReader|ClaudeLogReader|wait_for_event\(|wait_for_events\(|wait_for_message\(" bin/ask` returns nothing
close_reason: ask now sends directly to tmux/wezterm panes; ccb-mounted no longer pings daemons

title: Robustness: eliminate hangs, stale state, and lock races
description:
Epic for CCB robustness improvements.

## Scope
1. RPC timeouts + deadline propagation (Critical)
2. Atomic state writes + validation helper (Critical)
3. Lock robustness - TOCTOU, FD leaks (Critical)
4. Stale state detection - TTL, pid checks (High)
5. Replace bare exception handlers (High)

## Success Criteria
- No socket operations can hang indefinitely
- State file writes are atomic and validated
- Lock acquisition is race-free
- Stale sessions are detected and cleaned up
- Exceptions are typed and debuggable

title: RPC: add per-recv timeouts + request deadlines
description:
Add hard timeouts to all RPC/socket I/O to prevent indefinite hangs.

## Files
- lib/askd_client.py
- lib/askd_rpc.py
- bin/ask

## Implementation
- Add socket.settimeout() for all recv operations
- Implement deadline propagation (pass timeout_s down call stack)
- Wrap decode loops with deadline checks
- Surface single timeout error type (CCBTimeoutError)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Every connect/send/recv has bounded timeout
- [ ] Global request deadline prevents partial-read hangs
- [ ] Consistent timeout error type surfaced to callers
- [ ] Tests for timeout scenarios

title: State: atomic writes + JSON validation helper
description:
Make session/state writes atomic and add validation.

## Files
- lib/session_utils.py
- lib/pane_registry.py
- daemon state writers

## Implementation
- Standardize: temp file ‚Üí fsync ‚Üí os.replace ‚Üí chmod(0o600)
- Create read_json_state(path, schema=None) helper
- Add minimal schema validation for required keys/types
- Replace scattered json.loads() with validated reads

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All state writes use atomic pattern
- [ ] Validation helper with schema support
- [ ] File permissions hardened (0o600)
- [ ] Tests for concurrent write scenarios

title: Locks: fix TOCTOU + FD leaks; add contention tests
description:
Eliminate TOCTOU races and FD leaks in lock implementation.

## Files
- lib/process_lock.py

## Implementation
- Use single open FD with O_CLOEXEC, always closed on retry/failure
- Rely on OS primitives (exclusive create / flock) not check-then-create
- Add contention tests: multiple processes competing for same lock

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No TOCTOU window in lock acquisition
- [ ] No FD leaks on retry/failure paths
- [ ] Tests: one winner, no leaked FDs, bounded wait, cleanup on crash
- [ ] Works correctly on Windows and Unix

title: Registry: stale detection (TTL, pid checks, self-heal)
description:
Add stale state detection and isolation tightening.

## Files
- lib/pane_registry.py
- lib/claude_comm.py
- state readers

## Implementation
- Add owner identity fields: created_at, last_seen_at, pid, instance token
- Verify pid is alive on read (best-effort)
- Check timestamps within TTL, project key matches normalized workdir
- Provide --cleanup and self-heal paths

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Stale sessions detected by TTL and pid checks
- [ ] Invalid/stale state ignored and regenerated
- [ ] Self-heal path for corrupted state
- [ ] Tests for stale state scenarios

title: Errors: replace bare excepts; add debug diagnostics
description:
Systematically replace bare exception handlers with typed handling.

## Scope
~352 bare except handlers across ~42 files

## Implementation
- Triage into categories: file I/O, JSON parsing, subprocess, sockets
- Replace with narrow exception types
- When CCB_DEBUG=1, emit structured diagnostics to stderr/log
- Make recovery behavior intentional and debuggable

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No bare except: or except Exception: without justification
- [ ] CCB_DEBUG=1 shows structured error info
- [ ] Recovery behavior is explicit and documented
- [ ] Tests for error recovery paths
